modules.title: Module 1: SDLC Fundamentals
modules.description: Understanding the Software Development Life Cycle.

lessons.title: What is SDLC?
lessons.theory: The Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) is a structured process used by the software industry to design, develop, and test high-quality software. The SDLC aims to produce software that meets or exceeds customer expectations, reaches completion within time and cost estimates, and is maintainable and scalable. It provides a well-defined framework for all the activities that take place during the software development process.
lessons.code:
SDLC Phases:
1. Planning
2. Analysis
3. Design
4. Implementation
5. Testing
6. Maintenance

lessons.title: SDLC Phases
lessons.theory:
The SDLC is composed of several distinct phases, each with its own set of activities and deliverables. While the exact names can vary, they generally follow this sequence:

1. Planning & Requirement Analysis

This is the most important phase. Business requirements are gathered and analyzed by senior members of the team. This stage involves understanding the problem, defining the project goals, and creating a project plan.

2. Design

The system and software design is prepared from the requirement specifications. This helps in specifying hardware and system requirements and also helps in defining the overall system architecture.

3. Implementation/Coding

On receiving system design documents, the work is divided into modules/units and actual coding is started. This is the longest phase of the SDLC.

4. Testing

After the code is developed, it is tested against the requirements to make sure that the product is actually solving the needs addressed and gathered during the requirements phase. During this phase, all types of functional testing like unit testing, integration testing, system testing, acceptance testing are done.

5. Deployment

Once the software is certified and no bugs or errors are stated, then it is deployed to the production environment.

6. Maintenance

Once the system is deployed, and customers start using the developed system, issues may come up and need to be fixed from time to time. This process where the care is taken for the developed product is known as maintenance.
lessons.code:
Key Phases:
- Requirement Gathering
- System Design
- Coding
- Testing
- Deployment

quiz.question: In which phase is the code actually written?

lessons.title: Waterfall Basics
lessons.theory:
The Waterfall Model is the most traditional SDLC model, following a strict, linear-sequential flow. Each phase must be fully completed before the next phase can begin.

1. Requirements

All possible requirements of the system to be developed are captured in this phase and documented in a requirement specification document.

2. Design

The requirement specifications from the first phase are studied in this phase and the system design is prepared. This system design helps in specifying hardware and system requirements and also helps in defining the overall system architecture.

3. Implementation

With inputs from the system design, the system is first developed in small programs called units, which are integrated in the next phase. Each unit is developed and tested for its functionality, which is referred to as Unit Testing.

4. Verification (Testing)

All the units developed in the implementation phase are integrated into a system after testing of each unit. Post-integration the entire system is tested for any faults and failures.

5. Maintenance

This is the final phase. There are some issues which come up in the client environment. To fix those issues, patches are released. Also to enhance the product, some better versions are released. Maintenance is done to deliver these changes in the customer environment.
lessons.code:
Waterfall Flow:
Requirements -> Design -> Implementation -> Verification -> Maintenance

lessons.title: Pros & Cons
lessons.theory:
The Waterfall model has distinct advantages and disadvantages.

Pros

  • Simple and Clear: It's easy to understand, manage, and follow because the stages are rigid and well-defined.
  • Well-Documented: Each phase has specific deliverables and a review process, leading to thorough documentation.
  • Good for Small Projects: It works well for smaller projects where requirements are very well understood and are not expected to change.

Cons

  • Inflexible: It is very rigid and does not allow for changes once a phase is complete.
  • High Risk: If a mistake is found in an early phase, it is very costly to fix it in a later phase.
  • No Working Software Until Late: A working version of the software is not produced until late in the life cycle.
lessons.code:
Best for:
- Small projects
- Requirements are well understood
- Technology is understood

quiz.question: When is Waterfall NOT recommended?
options: Projects with high risk of changing requirements

lessons.title: Agile Manifesto
lessons.theory:
Agile is a mindset and a set of values and principles, not a single methodology. It's an iterative approach to project management and software development that helps teams deliver value to their customers faster.

The Agile Manifesto

The core ideas are captured in the Agile Manifesto, which prioritizes:

  • Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
  • Working software over comprehensive documentation
  • Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
  • Responding to change over following a plan

The Agile Process Flow

Unlike the linear Waterfall model, Agile works in cycles (iterations). A typical cycle includes:

  • 1. Requirements: Defining a small set of features to build next.
  • 2. Development: Coding and implementing these features.
  • 3. Testing: Verifying functionality immediately.
  • 4. Delivery: Releasing the increment to stakeholders.
  • 5. Feedback: Gathering input to guide the next cycle.
lessons.code:
Agile Values:
- Individuals and interactions
- Working software
- Customer collaboration
- Responding to change

quiz.question: What does Agile value more than comprehensive documentation?

lessons.title: Scrum Framework
lessons.theory:
Scrum is the most popular framework for implementing Agile. It is designed for teams of ten or fewer members, who break their work into goals that can be completed within time-boxed iterations, called Sprints (usually 2-4 weeks long). Key components include:

Roles

  • Product Owner: The 'voice of the customer'. They are responsible for maximizing the value of the product. They manage the Product Backlog, ensuring it is visible, transparent, and clear to all. They decide what needs to be built.
  • Scrum Master: A servant-leader for the Scrum Team. They help everyone understand Scrum theory, practices, rules, and values. They coach the team in self-organization and help remove impediments (blockers) to the team's progress.
  • Development Team: A self-organizing, cross-functional group of professionals who do the actual work of delivering a potentially releasable Increment of 'Done' product at the end of each Sprint.

Events

  • Sprint Planning: A meeting where the entire Scrum Team collaborates to define the work to be performed in the upcoming Sprint and how it will be achieved.
  • Daily Scrum: A 15-minute time-boxed event for the Development Team to synchronize activities, discuss progress, and plan for the next 24 hours. Often called a 'stand-up'.
  • Sprint Review: Held at the end of the Sprint to inspect the Increment and adapt the Product Backlog if needed. The team demonstrates what they built to stakeholders.
  • Sprint Retrospective: An opportunity for the Scrum Team to inspect itself (people, relationships, process, tools) and create a plan for improvements to be enacted during the next Sprint.

Artifacts

  • Product Backlog: An ordered list of everything that is known to be needed in the product. It is the single source of requirements.
  • Sprint Backlog: The set of Product Backlog items selected for the Sprint, plus a plan for delivering the product Increment.
  • Increment: The sum of all the Product Backlog items completed during a Sprint and the value of the increments of all previous Sprints. It must be in usable condition.
lessons.code:
Scrum Roles:
- Product Owner
- Scrum Master
- Development Team

lessons.title: Kanban
lessons.theory:
Kanban is an Agile framework focused on visualizing work, limiting work in progress (WIP), and maximizing flow. It uses a Kanban board to represent work items.

Key Principles:

  • Visualize Workflow: The board shows the current state of every task. Common columns include:
    • To Do: A backlog of tasks waiting to be started.
    • In Progress: Tasks that the team is actively working on. The number of items here is often limited (WIP Limit) to prevent multitasking and improve focus.
    • Done: Completed tasks.
  • Limit Work in Progress (WIP): By setting a maximum number of items per column, the team can identify bottlenecks and improve throughput.
  • Manage Flow: The goal is to move work smoothly through the process from 'To Do' to 'Done' as quickly as possible.
lessons.code:
Kanban Board Columns:
- To Do
- In Progress
- Done

quiz.question: What is the main focus of Kanban?
options: Visualizing work and limiting work in progress

lessons.title: Agile vs. Waterfall
lessons.theory:
Choosing the right methodology is critical for project success. Here is how they compare:

Waterfall

  • Structure: Linear and sequential. Like a relay race, the baton is passed only when a lap is finished.
  • Flexibility: Rigid. Changes are difficult and costly once a phase is complete.
  • Risk: High risk of building the wrong thing, as testing happens at the end.
  • Best For: Projects with fixed, clear requirements, strict deadlines, or regulatory compliance needs (e.g., construction, medical devices).

Agile

  • Structure: Iterative and cyclic. Work is broken into small chunks.
  • Flexibility: Highly flexible. Changes are welcomed even late in development.
  • Risk: Lower risk, as testing and feedback happen continuously.
  • Best For: Projects with evolving requirements, startups, or when rapid user feedback is needed (e.g., mobile apps, SaaS products).

Key Differences

While Waterfall focuses on upfront planning and documentation ('Plan-driven'), Agile focuses on adaptability and delivering working software frequently ('Value-driven').
lessons.code:
Comparison Summary:
Waterfall = Linear, Rigid, Plan-Driven
Agile = Iterative, Flexible, Value-Driven

modules.title: Module 4: DevOps
modules.description: Bridging the gap between development and operations.

lessons.title: What is DevOps?
lessons.theory:
DevOps is a cultural philosophy and set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops). It aims to shorten the development life cycle and provide continuous delivery with high software quality by automating and integrating the processes between development and operations teams.

The DevOps Lifecycle:

  • Plan: Define features and requirements.
  • Code: Develop the code and manage it with version control (e.g., Git).
  • Build: Compile the code into a runnable artifact (Continuous Integration).
  • Test: Run automated tests to ensure quality.
  • Release: Prepare the artifact for deployment.
  • Deploy: Push the release to the production environment (Continuous Deployment).
  • Operate: Manage and maintain the application in production.
  • Monitor: Collect feedback and performance data to feed back into the planning phase.
lessons.code:
DevOps Cycle:
Plan -> Code -> Build -> Test -> Release -> Deploy -> Operate -> Monitor

quiz.question: What is the main goal of DevOps?
options: To separate Dev and Ops teams
To shorten the development life cycle
